text: Your Tuesday Evening BriefingHere’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
The Book Review PodcastLauren Sandler talks about “This Is All I Got.”
In the ‘DealBook’ NewsletterJesus, the Beatles and … Masa Son?

W.H.O. Members Reject Trump’s Demands, but Will Study Virus ResponseThe outcome left the U.S. isolated as officials from China, Russia and the European Union chided President Trump’s threats to leave the organization.Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and the Federal Reserve chair, Jerome Powell, offered lawmakers a stark assessment of the fragile state of the economy.Missouri carried out the nation’s first execution in months. Here’s the latest.
Too Big to Fail: The Entire Private SectorLarge parts of financial markets are now being managed by the government. Even if they don’t like it, investors must acknowledge it.

Find the highest risk U.S. counties
Economy
Top policymakers warn that the economy is likely to weaken before a turnaround begins.
Layoffs of state and local workers could slow the economic recovery, the Fed chair says.
The unemployment rate will hit 15 percent, the Congressional Budget Office predicts.
Global
W.H.O. agrees to investigate global response as China and America bicker.
Cambridge University announces that it will hold all lectures online for the next academic year.
A 100-year-old who raised millions for British health workers by doing 100 laps on a patio will be knighted.
New York
Some N.Y. hospitals will allow visits to resume under a pilot program.
N.Y.U. plans to hold in-person classes, ‘with great care,’ this fall.
N.J. revises how it counts nursing home deaths.
One Crisis Too Many: How the Virus Pushed Germany to Shift CourseSome may not like it back home, but in the twilight of her career, Angela Merkel joined with France to try to save the European Union.
Young Workers May Never Recover From the DownturnThose entering the job market may never catch up in pay, opportunities or confidence.

‘Way Too Late’: Inside Amazon’s Biggest OutbreakA warehouse in the foothills of the Poconos has had more known Covid-19 cases than any of Amazon’s others after missing early opportunities to protect workers.

Isolated Key West Will Reopen. For Some People, It Will Be Too Late.The archipelago has been accessible since late March mainly to those who live or work there, keeping the number of Covid-19 cases low. But what happens now?

At Fox News, Mixed Message on Malaria Drug: ‘Very Safe’ vs. ‘It Will Kill You’Laura Ingraham backed President Trump after he said he was taking hydroxychloroquine, but Neil Cavuto warned viewers about the risks.
Is the pandemic causing suicides to rise?

Johnson & Johnson to End Talc-Based Baby Powder Sales in North AmericaThe company has faced lawsuits from cancer patients who claim that its talc was contaminated with a known carcinogen, and that the company knew of the risks.
Watch our investigation into claims about baby powder in an episode of “The Weekly” from last fall.
After years of increasing tensions that nearly led to war, Iran has shifted from a policy of provocation to one of limited cooperation.
Annie Glenn with her husband, the astronaut John Glenn, at Cape Canaveral in Florida in 1962. Associated Press

Yu Lihua, 90, Dies; Writer Spoke to ‘Rootless’ Chinese ÉmigrésIn her fiction she depicted “the struggle of Chinese immigrants in American society” — not the “Oriental exoticism” preferred by many publishers in the ’60s.
Those We’ve LostThe pandemic has taken an incalculable death toll. This series is designed to put names and faces to the numbers.
